narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed the ability to read, speak, and write simplified Chinese.
I learned enough Chinese to have simple conversations with other speakers.
I learned quite a bit of basic Chinese
Basic skills necessary for reading and speaking Chinese.
I learned the basics of speaking, listening, reading, and writing in the Chinese language. I also learned how to learn a language. This will be incredibly useful in the future.
Chinese!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:  interesting, engaging, well-paced, organized 

Weaknesses: fast-paced, heavy workload, lots of content
The class time was used to its full potential.
The course was quite fast-paced, which was both a strength because we learned a ton and a weakness because it was overwhelming at times. Overall, I'm very impressed by the Chinese program at Yale.

The strengths of this course are the frequent meeting times and the interactive format of the live class sessions. Furthermore, the weekly individual session with our teacher was very helpful. However, the primary weakness was the rather unusual grading. Many percentages - some of which were comically small (3%, 1%, etc) - and extra points that never seemed to factor into our grade. More transparent grading is only fair. I just wanted to know what my grade is in the class.

Really well conducted course although the workload is really high. Teacher was really on students about homework. Cant really miss assignments as you are expected to turn it in late anyways. Brutal, but very very effective

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms were helpful for allowing students to practice their skills in a more personal setting. Regular character writing and typing practice quizzes over Zoom chat and Zoom white board were helpful.

Online-specific practices that worked:
- Li Laoshi used breakout rooms effectively

I'm concerned that I will not be prepared for in-person Chinese language learning because we did not learn how to write characters by hand. We almost exclusively learned how to type characters. However, I've heard from Chinese friends that typing characters is a more important skill than writing them in 21st century China.
This course was excellent in the way it adapted. The course was engaging and I learned a remarkable amount.

Well done besides quizzes and exams and learning how to write Chinese. 

Writing Chinese. Not a thing I felt like I leaned in the course. Whatever I crammed for the exam i I have already lost. 

Quizzes and exams. Format for the final was not very Friendly for those with weak internet connections and still left a lot of room for cheating but I felt like was the only format that came close to not allowing students to cheat on an exam. Chapter tests where we were just on video while taking the exam makes it very easy to cheat. Felt like that was the case given the really high averages for the cheaper tests unless I am mistaken and that is the average haven ven in previous years

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I don't have experience with other language departments at Yale, but for a language commonly regarded as the hardest in the world to learn, I learned a lot. The content is organized well. I am shocked at the amount I retained. The teachers put time into giving you commentary and fixing your pronunciation. Yes, it was a large time commitment, but I looked forward to the daily lectures more than my lighter courses. Great intro course. Still, only take if you are truly interested in the language and willing to work to improve.

If you're looking for a language credit and you don't mind a demanding workload, this class is for you. If you're interested in learning the Chinese language this course is also for you. 

But, if you're looking for a hard language for the sake of learning a hard language, you should reconsider taking Chinese.
Yes! I loved Li Laoshi and definitely learned a lot of Chinese.
Despite the large workload, it is satisfying to be able to learn a new language.
Yes! Very rewarding! I've learned so much in so little time.
Yes. This is so worth it to learn Chinese.
